awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Research on a Novel Double-Pulse Laser Micro Sintering Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Selective laser sintering (SLS) is an additive manufacturing process capable of rapidly and flexibly producing complex metallic parts.  An SLS process, which is set up to manufacture micron sized components or components with micron scale features, can be called 'laser micro sintering' (LMS). One challenge associated with LMS is that fully dense metallic components are difficult to achieve. Through this award a novel double-pulse laser micro sintering process (DP-LMS) will be investigated. This new process has the potential to enhance the densification (reduce internal voids), and hence improve the  mechanical properties of parts produced by LMS. The research focuses on understanding the material's transient responses during the DP-LMS process, and subsequently establishing the relevant process-structure-property relationships. The knowledge gained is also potentially relevant to other material processing and synthesis processes involving metal powder sintering. Successful implementation of the DP-LMS process has great potential to positively impact applications that may benefit from rapid and flexible fabrication of complex components with micron scale aspects such as MEMS, or micro medical devices. It is expected that both graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the research, and that process principles and/or new findings will be incorporated directly into a current manufacturing classes and a video that will be made available to the public. 
 
The specific research objectives are: (1) to test the hypothesis that during DP-LMS, suitably sending the two pulses can effectively help material densification with little increase of its surface roughness; (2) fundamentally understand the heat transfer, phase change, melt flow, and densification process in the target material during DP-LMS; and (3) establish the process-structure-property relationships for the DP-LMS process. The research tasks include: (1) in-situ study of the DP-LMS process using fast pyrometry, fast imaging, and emission spectroscopy to measure target temperatures, surface morphology variations, and plasma properties. (2) Development of a continuum-mechanics based model to understand the thermal and fluid transport and phase changes in the target material during the DP-LMS process. The model will be validated by the experimental measurements in task 1. And (3), characterization of the sintered material microstructures and mechanical properties through optical and electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction and hardness testing.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project involves the study of the double-pulse laser micro sintering (DP-LMS) process for metallic materials. DP-LMS is a novel micro additive manufacturing process utilizing two types of laser pulses the PI proposed previously. Typically it utilizes "sintering laser pulses" with a low power density to melt particles and then "pressing laser pulse(s)" with a higher power density at a controlled delay time to produce high pressure via laser-generated plasma to promote melt flow for less balling and/or better material densification upon solidification. Such a pulse pattern will be repeated as the laser spots scan the surface of the powder bed.   

 

Intellectual Merit

In this project, both experimental and modeling studies were performed for DP-LMS, including time-resolved in-situ imaging, temperature and optical emission spectroscopy measurements, post-process microstructure and mechanical property characterizations, physics-based thermal, gas dynamics and fluid flow modeling, as well as artificial neutral network (ANN) and response surface (RS) modeling.  

DP-LMS experiments were conducted for different types of powders, such as cobalt, iron, copper, aluminum, nickel and silver. Under the conditions studied, it was discovered that DP-LMS can fabricate much more continuous and/or densified material shown in micrographs than LMS using only sintering pulses (called "SP-LMS") for cobalt, iron, copper, and aluminum powders. Some parameters' effects and general parameter selection guidelines were revealed from the experimental study. Compared with SP-LMS, the surface of a thin layer sintered by DP-LMS can appear smoother in a scanning electron microscopic (SEM) image for cobalt due to much less balling, and not much rougher for iron. A thin layer made by DP-LMS can have a larger variation in its surface vertical location in a sufficiently large spatial range. This could be because the thin layer by DP-LMS has much higher densification than SP-LMS, and thus can have more severe thermal deformation (thermal deformation and stress is also a well-known challenge in conventional selective lase melting). For the nickel powder used, both DP-LMS and SP-LMS can produce reasonably densified single tracks. For the silver powder utilized and under the conditions studied, SP-LMS was unable to produce good sintering results. So was DP-LMS, likely due to silver's easiness in vaporization.  

For DP-LMS of the iron powder, under the conditions investigated, DP-LMS can lead to a surface porosity (i.e., surface pore area percentage) much lower than SP-LMS (~3.4% vs. ~19.0%). A small grain size typically on the scale of ~1 to ~3 μm can be produced. The sintered iron material shows very high nanohardness measured, for which the small grain size and/or martensite existence is the expected reason.   

Thermal modeling of cobalt powder bed temperature changes was performed. Under the condition studied, the model prediction shows a reasonably good agreement with the measured surface temperature history induced by sintering pulses. Physics-based thermal and gas dynamic modeling was conducted for plasma evolution in DP-LMS of cobalt, which shows acceptable agreements with experimentally obtained plasma top front propagation, free electron number density and temperature. The model simulation shows that the plasma can result in very high pressure onto the surface of the powder bed. Using the pressure, a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model shows the pressure can drive the coalition of two micro droplets of molten cobalt initially close to each other, supporting the DP-LMS mechanism introduced in the first paragraph. A 3D physics-based (PB) thermal model was developed for the powder bed temperature field in DP-LMS, and its calculation results were utilized to train ANN and RS models. An ANN model can have a better agreement with the PB prediction, but require a longer computing time than a RS model.

The research in this project has improved the understanding of the transient material responses during DP-LMS as well as microstructures and mechanical property of material sintered by DP-LMS. The research contributes to the building of a science base that is important for the future development and potential practical applications of DP-LMS.  

 

Broader Impact

The research in this project contributes to the building of a science base for DP-LMS, which could potentially help the improvement of densification and mechanical properties of parts produced by laser micro sintering. This may contribute to the promotion or enabling of many applications of laser micro sintering, and broadly impact fields that could benefit from the production of micro metal parts through laser micro sintering.  In the entire project, a total of ~6 PhD students advised by the PI and many undergraduate students (without being paid by this grant) were involved in related work. So far, five journal papers have been published or accepted for publication, and one patent on DP-LMS has been granted. PI incorporated some contents related to DP-LMS into a manufacturing course. PI also introduced project-related information in a lab tour to students in a summer Engineering Academic Boot Camp organized by Purdue Minority Engineering Program. 

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2023
Modified by: Benxin Wu
